posts.cooked: The shelves/nodes in this game encourage a top-heavy robot, but the charge station seems like it would punish robots for being too top-heavy. Have any teams struggled with this or found solutions? Is the charge station as punishing as it seems?

Watching the first week zero the charge station had several high center of gravity victims that were tipped.  Even some that had some driving errors with relatively low CG.

The interaction of the two make a pretty decent design challenge this year.

If it were strictly a shooting game and no need for a high placement the charging station would be too easy in my opinion, but with the addition of the pick and place and need to keep CG low it makes for a interesting combination.

I think a large amount teams will end on their side at least once this year from the charge station.  Either by trying to drive around it and ramping half their bot up the side.  Trying to triple balance and slipping off‚Ä¶

posts.name: Evan Kruger
posts.cooked: Another problem with a top heavy robot is that driving becomes very unstable, so a lower center of gravity is much better when possible. There are several solutions to a high center of gravity that don‚Äôt include redesigning the robot. The cheaper option that many teams opt for is putting weights at the bottom of their robot until they max out the 125 pound limit (see the 2023 Everybot for an example). Some other teams have gone for steel belly pans, adding 20-30 pounds at the very bottom (see 5727 Omegabytes on Open Alliance).

posts.name: Peter Matteson
posts.cooked:
Top heavy robots are always a problem because it‚Äôs easy to get out of sorts and tip or get tipped from incidental contact.  Every game with a ramp like structure exacerbates this (03, 04, 06, 07 on other robots, 10, 12, etc) and teams learn that they should have kept their weight low or figured out how to properly ballast their robot.

It seems like every time a field like this comes around teams have to relearn what they should already know and do with every robot.  Keep your weight low, and if you have anything to spare for the limit ballast in the best location to avoid tipping.

We replaced our pocketed aluminum electronics belly pan with a 3/16" solid steel one to add 25 pounds down low. After having done so we are still under max weight by ten pounds, as our upper robot has only two motors on it. We also designed to ensure that when traveling all of our reach stuff is stowed low and inside the frame perimeter. posts.name: GaryVoshol
posts.cooked: Tuck your arms in when you drive. Not only will that help alleviate being top-heavy, it will help you avoid G204/205/206 calls.

We are adding weight to the bottom. We also decreased the acceleration/deceleration in the code, which works really well on the ground but doesn‚Äôt really solve the charge station. Do you think that moving the arm in front of the robot when going onto the charge station and then taking it back down before the station balances would work, or is that just a great way to land on and damage our arm?

posts.name: Carl Hauser
posts.cooked: The problem with extending forward is that then if you go past the balance point you‚Äôll tend to tip forward. In some cases it may be necessary to go past the balance point in order to start the charging station toward level and then quickly move back. If you‚Äôre not quick enough, over you go (speaking from experience). It might be helpful but has to be done with care.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Honestly I am more concerned with top-heavy robots and full speed collisions midfield. There is going to be some nasty foul debate when people become tangled or otherwise limited.

posts.name: Fields
posts.cooked: We‚Äôll def be watching this over the next couple of week.  We have a fairly low bot that‚Äôs quite the pusher. Obviously we don‚Äôt want to damage anyone, but I‚Äôm a little worried the refs may treat taller bots like quarterbacks, particularly at full speeds.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
GaryVoshol:

Tuck your arms in when you drive.

^^ This.

Also, make sure that when your arm is tucked in, your CoG is low.  As a quick example, do not mount motors or gearboxes on the ‚Äúshoulder‚Äù of your arm - put the motor and gearbox near the base and drive the sholder arm from there using (or example) chain or belt.

You may also want to consider an arm that only holds and places game pieces (e.g. a pneumatic claw), and have a separate low-COG intake that pulls pieces into where the arm can grip them.
My team had an extremely top heavy robot and to compensate for it we‚Äôre trying to use our arm to extend and counterbalance while going up the charge pad.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Yeah despite awareness of the issue there is only so much one can do with shields and other things to prevent getting tangled
